factoid: Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev was the traveler.
Pierre saw Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev from the postmaster’s book.
Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev had been one of the best-known Freemasons and Martinists even in Novíkov’s time.
After Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev had gone, Pierre did not go to bed or order horses.
After Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev had gone, Pierre paced up and down the room.
Pierre pondered over his own vicious past.
Pierre pictured to himself a blissful, irreproachable, virtuous future that seemed easy.
Pierre believed that his viciousness was caused by forgetting how good it is to be virtuous.
No trace of Pierre’s former doubts remained in his soul.
Pierre firmly believed in the possibility of a brotherhood of men united in supporting one another in the path of virtue.
Freemasonry presented itself to Pierre as such a brotherhood.
Upon reaching Petersburg, Pierre did not let anyone know of his arrival.
Pierre spent whole days reading Thomas à Kempis in Petersburg.
Thomas à Kempis’s book had been sent to Pierre by someone unknown.
While reading Thomas à Kempis’s book, Pierre continually realized the joy of believing in the possibility of attaining perfection.
While reading Thomas à Kempis’s book, Pierre realized the joy of believing in the possibility of active brotherly love among men.
Joseph Alexéevich Bazdéev had revealed to Pierre that active brotherly love among men was possible.
A week after arriving in Petersburg, Willarski, a young Polish count whom Pierre had known slightly in Petersburg society, entered Pierre’s room.
Willarski addressed Pierre in an official and ceremonious manner.
Willarski said he had come with a message and an offer.
A person of very high standing in the Brotherhood had applied for Pierre to be received into the Order before the usual term.
Willarski proposed to be Pierre’s sponsor.
Willarski considered it a sacred duty to fulfill the high-standing person’s wishes.
Willarski asked Pierre if he wished to enter the Brotherhood of Freemasons under his sponsorship.
Pierre answered that he wished to enter the Brotherhood of Freemasons under Willarski’s sponsorship.
Willarski bowed his head after Pierre’s answer.
Willarski asked Pierre whether he had renounced his former convictions and whether he believed in God.
Pierre considered the question.
Pierre answered that he believed in God.
Willarski repeated that Pierre believed in God.
Willarski said that in that case they could go.
Willarski said his carriage was at Pierre’s service.
Willarski was silent throughout the drive.
Willarski replied that brothers more worthy than him would test Pierre.
Willarski told Pierre that Pierre had only to tell the truth.
Willarski and Pierre entered the courtyard of a large house where the Lodge had its headquarters.
Willarski and Pierre ascended a dark staircase.
Willarski and Pierre entered a small well-lit anteroom.
Willarski and Pierre took off their cloaks without a servant’s aid.
Willarski and Pierre passed into another room.
A man in strange attire appeared at the door.
Willarski stepped toward the man and said something to him in French in an undertone.
Willarski went up to a small wardrobe.
Pierre noticed garments that he had never seen before.
Willarski took a kerchief from the cupboard.
Willarski bound Pierre’s eyes with the kerchief and tied it in a knot behind.
The knot caught some of Pierre’s hairs painfully.
Willarski drew his face down, kissed Pierre, and took Pierre by the hand and led him forward.
The knot hurt Pierre, leaving lines of pain on his face and a shamefaced smile.
Willarski stopped after about ten paces.
Willarski told Pierre that whatever happens to Pierre, Pierre must bear it all manfully if Pierre has firmly resolved to join the Brotherhood.
Pierre nodded affirmatively.
Willarski told Pierre that when Pierre hears a knock at the door, Pierre will uncover his eyes.
Willarski wished Pierre courage and success.
Willarski pressed Pierre’s hand and then went out.
